prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to continue this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
The baby suffered a cardiac arrest at the theme park on Thursday

A woman has been arrested on suspicion of neglecting a five-month-old boy who suffered a cardiac arrest at a theme park.

The baby is in a critical condition in hospital following the incident at Legoland Windsor at about 13:00 BST on Thursday, police said.

A 27-year-old woman from Witham, Essex, was arrested on suspicion of neglecting a child to cause unnecessary injury.

She has been released on bail until 26 July.

Det Con Zoe Eele, of Thames Valley Police's Child Abuse Investigation Unit, said: "Firstly, our thoughts are with the family of the boy who is in a critical condition in hospital after suffering a cardiac arrest.

"We are working closely with the team at Legoland Windsor Resort but would like to speak to anyone who have information about this incident, specifically anyone who was queueing for the Coastguard HQ boat ride between around 11.30am and 12:45pm.

"I would ask for the public to please avoid speculation about the incident and to respect the boy's family at this deeply upsetting time."

Police said they are not looking for further suspects in relation to the incident.

In a statement, the theme park said: "On Thursday, a young guest was taken ill... and our fully trained First Aid team administered immediate care until the emergency services arrived.

"We will continue to support Thames Valley Police with their ongoing investigation."

Follow BBC South on Facebook, X, or Instagram. Send your story ideas to south.newsonline@bbc.co.uk or via WhatsApp on 0808 100 2240.

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.
stories: Police are appealing for anyone who was in the queue for the Coastguard HQ boat ride at Legoland Windsor Resort on Thursday to come forward and provide any information that may assist with their investigation.
It is believed that a dispute broke out between two families in the queue around 2pm, resulting in a verbal altercation that escalated into a physical fight.
Eyewitnesses reported hearing loud shouting and screaming as the two groups of people, estimated to be around 10-15 individuals, began throwing punches and pushing each other.
The altercation reportedly started near the entrance of the popular nightclub, with witnesses describing the scene as "chaotic" and "intense".
Eyewitnesses claim that the argument escalated quickly, with both parties shouting and gesturing wildly before punches were thrown.
The fight spilled out onto the sidewalk, with onlookers scattering to get out of the way as the two men wrestled each other to the ground.

Punches flew as they rolled around, the sound of grunting and snarling filling the air, until finally one of them managed to gain the upper hand and pinned the other's arm behind his back, shouting "You're going down, you piece of trash!"

The pinned fighter struggled to free himself, but the other's grip was too strong, and he was forced to submit, his face twisted in a mixture of anger and defeat as he glared up at his opponent, his eyes blazing with a fierce hatred.

The crowd erupted into cheers and chants, but the defeated fighter's gaze remained fixed on his opponent, his hatred burning brighter with every passing moment, as if he was already planning his revenge, his mind racing with strategies and tactics to turn the tables and emerge victorious in their next encounter.

The air was thick with tension as the two fighters faced off, their eyes locked in a silent challenge, the crowd's noise fading into the background as the defeated fighter's thoughts turned to the countless hours of training, the sacrifices made, and the doubts that had crept in, all of which now fueled his determination to exact his revenge.

His opponent, a towering figure with a chiseled jawline and a wicked grin, sneered at him, taunting him with a flick of his wrist, the crowd's roar growing louder as the tension mounted, the air electric with anticipation, the defeated fighter's eyes burning with a fierce intensity as he began to circle his opponent, searching for an opening, his mind racing with strategies and counterattacks, his fists clenched in anticipation of the battle to come.

The air was heavy with the scent of sweat and adrenaline as the two fighters faced off, their eyes locked in a fierce stare-down, the crowd's chanting growing more frenzied as the seconds ticked by, the defeated fighter's eyes never leaving his opponent's face, his mind racing with a single thought: revenge.

The sound of the bell ringing through the arena was like a spark igniting a fire in the defeated fighter's chest, and with a fierce determination burning within him, he charged forward, his fists flying in a blur of anger and desperation, his opponent meeting him blow for blow in a flurry of punches and kicks that sent the crowd into a frenzy, the air thick with the smell of blood and broken dreams.

As the two fighters clashed, the arena's lights seemed to dim, as if the very fabric of reality was bending to accommodate the intensity of their battle, the sound of their punches and kicks echoing off the walls like a primal chant, the defeated fighter's eyes locked on his opponent's with a fierce hunger, his mind consumed by the singular desire to emerge victorious, to prove to himself and the world that he was more than just a defeated soul, that he was a warrior, a champion, a force to be reckoned with.

The air was electric with tension as the fighters circled each other, their breathing heavy and labored, their eyes burning with a fierce determination, the crowd's collective energy building to a crescendo as they sensed the outcome of the battle hanging precariously in the balance, the defeated fighter's gaze never wavering from his opponent's, his mind racing with strategies and counterattacks, his body coiled like a spring, ready to unleash a devastating strike at any moment, the champion's eyes, on the other hand, gleamed with a cold, calculating intensity, his expression a mask of confidence and superiority, his movements fluid and precise, as if he were dancing to the rhythm of his own private drumbeat.

The champion's gloved hand shot out, a blur of motion as he unleashed a lightning-fast combination of punches, each one landing with precision and power, the defeated fighter stumbling backward under the onslaught, his eyes darting wildly around the ring in search of an opening, his mouth open in a silent scream as he struggled to defend against the relentless assault, the crowd erupting into a frenzy of cheers and chants as the champion's dominance became increasingly apparent, the defeated fighter's legs buckling beneath him as he crashed to the canvas, the referee's count hovering ominously over his head.

The referee's voice boomed through the arena, "Ten... nine... eight... seven... six... five... four... three... two... one... IT'S ALL OVER! THE CHAMPION HAS RETAINED HIS TITLE!" The crowd erupted into a deafening roar, the champion's arms raised in triumph as he stood over his defeated opponent, his gloved hands still clenched into fists, his chest heaving with exertion.

As the champion's music blared through the speakers, he made his way to the ropes, shaking hands with his opponent and exchanging words of respect before turning to soak in the adoration of the crowd. The defeated challenger, meanwhile, trudged back to his corner, his head hung low in defeat, his cornermen trying to console him as he struggled to come to terms with the outcome.

The champion's entourage, a bevy of beautiful women and burly bodyguards, surrounded him, cheering and chanting his name as he basked in the glory of his victory. The defeated challenger, still trying to process the crushing defeat, could feel the weight of his failure bearing down on him, the sting of defeat burning in his eyes as he gazed out at the sea of faces, each one a reminder of his own inadequacy.

As the champion's entourage continued to revel in their hero's triumph, the defeated challenger's thoughts turned to the words of his coach, echoing in his mind like a mantra of disappointment: "You had one shot, and you blew it." The weight of those words threatened to crush him, as he felt the sting of defeat burning in his eyes, and the sea of faces before him seemed to grow darker, like a stormy sea, each one a reminder of his own inadequacy.

The sound of his own heavy breathing was the only thing that broke the silence, as he stood there, frozen in shame, his eyes scanning the crowd for a glimpse of his coach's disapproving face, his mind replaying every moment of the match, every missed opportunity, every miscalculated move, until the memories became a jumbled mess of regret and frustration, and he felt like he was drowning in a sea of his own failures.

His coach's voice echoed in his mind, a harsh criticism that had cut deep, and he could feel the sting of tears pricking at the corners of his eyes, but he refused to let them fall, refused to show weakness in front of his teammates, who were all staring at him with a mixture of disappointment and pity, their faces a blur of sympathetic expressions that only made him feel more ashamed, and he knew he had to get out of there, away from the weight of his own inadequacy, before he completely lost himself in the darkness of his own failure.

He turned and walked away, the sound of his coach's words still ringing in his ears, the weight of his own disappointment crushing him, and he couldn't help but wonder how he had let it all slip away, how he had gone from being a star player to a benchwarmer, and the thought of facing his teammates again, of having to explain his latest mistake, was almost too much to bear, so he just kept walking, putting one foot in front of the other, until he was sure he was out of sight, and then he finally let the tears fall, hot and bitter, as he slumped against the wall, feeling like he was drowning in a sea of his own regret.

He stayed there for a long time, the tears soaking into the wall as he replayed every mistake, every misstep, every moment that had led him to this point. The sound of his coach's voice still echoed in his mind, the words "you're not the player we thought you were" seared into his brain like a branding iron. He thought about all the times he'd let his teammates down, all the chances he'd blown, all the opportunities he'd squandered. The weight of his own failure was crushing him, and he felt like he was suffocating under the pressure.

As he stood there, the weight of his own failure bearing down on him, he felt a sense of desperation creeping in. He thought about all the what-ifs, all the could-haves, all the should-haves. He replayed the game in his mind, reliving every mistake, every misstep, every moment of doubt and uncertainty. The sound of his coach's voice grew louder, more menacing, and he felt like he was trapped in a never-ending nightmare from which he couldn't awaken.

His eyes scanned the empty locker room, the silence deafening, as he relived the final play over and over, wondering what he could have done differently. The smell of sweat and disappointment hung heavy in the air, and he felt like he was drowning in it. He thought about all the times he'd let his teammates down, all the times he'd failed to come through when it mattered most. The weight of his own inadequacy crushed him, and he felt like he was suffocating under the pressure of his own expectations.

He slumped against the cold metal of the locker, his eyes welling up with tears as he replayed the game's final seconds in his mind. Why had he hesitated? Why had he not trusted his instincts? The what-ifs swirled in his head like a toxic storm, making it hard to catch his breath. He thought about all the times he'd been praised for his clutch performances, all the times his teammates had looked up to him as a leader. Now, it seemed like a distant memory, a cruel joke played on him by his own mind. The locker room's fluorescent lights seemed to mock him, their harsh glow illuminating the darkness that had taken up residence in his soul.

As he stood there, lost in the agony of defeat, he became aware of the silence that had fallen over the locker room. His teammates, usually a boisterous bunch, were all staring at him with a mix of disappointment and concern. The coach, a gruff, no-nonsense man, was pacing back and forth, his eyes fixed on the floor. The only sound was the soft hum of the lights and the heavy breathing of the players, all of whom seemed to be waiting for him to say something, anything, to break the spell of defeat. But he couldn't. He was frozen, unable to move, unable to speak, unable to escape the crushing weight of his own failure.

His eyes felt dry and gritty, his vision blurring as he struggled to process the events that had just unfolded. The game had been a close one, but in the end, it was his mistake that had cost them the win. He could feel the weight of his teammates' gazes on him, their disappointment and frustration palpable. The coach's pacing had stopped, and he was now standing still, his eyes fixed on him with a mixture of disappointment and disgust. The silence was oppressive, heavy with unspoken words and unmet expectations.

The air was thick with tension as he slowly got to his feet, his movements deliberate and labored, as if he was wading through quicksand. He could feel the eyes of his teammates on him, like a physical weight, pressing down on him. The coach's gaze was like a cold, hard slap, a reminder of his failure. He avoided looking at either of them, his eyes scanning the empty seats of the stadium, anywhere but at the faces that seemed to be judging him. The silence was starting to feel like a scream in his ears, a deafening roar that threatened to consume him.

The sound of his own ragged breathing was the only thing that broke the silence, a harsh reminder that he was still alive, still standing. He could feel the sweat dripping down his face, mixing with the tears that pricked at the corners of his eyes. He took a deep breath, trying to calm the storm that was raging inside him, but it only seemed to make things worse. His vision began to blur, and he felt himself swaying slightly, as if the ground beneath his feet was shifting.

His hand instinctively reached out to grab onto something, anything, to steady himself, but there was nothing to hold onto. He stumbled forward, his legs trembling beneath him, and crashed to the ground with a thud. The impact sent a jolt of pain through his head, and he lay there, his eyes closed, his body wracked with sobs.

As the sobs subsided, he slowly opened his eyes to find himself in a dimly lit room, the walls closing in around him like a suffocating shroud. The air was thick with the scent of decay and rot, and he could feel the dampness seeping into his bones. He tried to sit up, but a wave of dizziness washed over him, forcing him back onto the cold, hard ground.

As he struggled to catch his breath, he noticed a faint light flickering in the corner of the room, casting eerie shadows on the walls. The air seemed to vibrate with an otherworldly energy, and he could feel the weight of unseen eyes upon him. Suddenly, the light grew brighter, illuminating the figure of a woman standing before him, her face deathly pale and her eyes sunken with a deep sadness.

Her eyes, once bright and full of life, now seemed to hold a deep despair, as if the weight of a thousand sorrows had crushed the spark within them. Her skin was as white as the marble that surrounded her, and her lips were thin and pale, as if they had been drained of all color and vitality. She did not move or speak, but simply stood before him, her gaze fixed on some point beyond his shoulder, as if she were beholding a horror that only she could see.

The air around her seemed to vibrate with a heavy silence, as if the very presence of her had sucked the sound from the world. He felt a shiver run down his spine as he gazed upon her, his eyes drawn to the dark circles beneath her eyes, like bruises on the delicate skin of a flower. The soft folds of her gown seemed to billow around her like a cloud, and yet she stood tall, a statue of sorrow, unmoving and unyielding.

Her eyes, two deep pools of sorrow, seemed to bore into his very soul, and he felt the weight of her grief settle upon him like a shroud. The silence between them grew thicker, a palpable thing that he could almost reach out and touch. He took a step closer, his heart pounding in his chest, and yet he felt frozen in place, unable to move or speak, as if the words had been stolen from him.

The air was heavy with unspoken emotions, and he could feel the tears pricking at the corners of her eyes, threatening to spill over at any moment. He reached out a trembling hand, hesitating for a moment before gently brushing a strand of hair behind her ear, his fingers grazing the soft curve of her jaw.

As he touched her, her gaze drifted up to meet his, and for a moment, they just stared at each other, the only sound the heavy beating of their hearts. The tension between them was palpable, a living thing that seemed to vibrate with every breath they took.

The air was charged with anticipation, and Emma's skin prickled with goosebumps as Jack's fingers brushed against hers, sending shivers down her spine. She felt like she was drowning in the depths of his eyes, the blue of which seemed to darken to a navy blue as he gazed at her.

As the silence between them grew thicker than the summer air, Emma's heart pounded in her chest like a drum, threatening to burst free from its confines. Jack's gaze never wavered, his eyes burning with an intensity that made her feel like she was the only person in the world.

The tension between them was palpable, like a live wire humming with electricity, and Emma could feel the hairs on the back of her neck standing on end as Jack's eyes seemed to bore into her very soul. She swallowed hard, her throat constricting with emotion, and her voice barely above a whisper, she asked, "What do you want, Jack?"
His eyes never leaving hers, Jack's voice was low and menacing as he replied, "I want the truth, Emma. I want to know why you're really here, and what you're hiding from me."

Emma's heart racing, she took a step back, her eyes darting around the dimly lit room as if searching for an escape, but her gaze was drawn back to Jack's intense stare. "I'm here because...because I had to get away," she stammered, her voice barely above a whisper.

The words hung in the air, heavy with unspoken secrets, as Jack's eyes seemed to bore deeper into hers, his gaze like a physical touch that made her skin prickle with unease. "From what?" he pressed, his voice low and husky, his words dripping with a mixture of curiosity and concern.

"Lies," she whispered, her voice barely audible over the pounding of her heart, her eyes darting around the room as if searching for an escape route, but finding none. "You're asking the wrong questions, Jack. You're not supposed to know any of this."

"I don't know what you're talking about," Jack lied, his voice steady, but his eyes locked onto hers, searching for any sign of what she was trying to hide. "What are you talking about, Emily? What secrets are you keeping from me?"

"Secrets?" Emily's voice was laced with innocence, but Jack's gaze saw right through it. "I'm not keeping any secrets, Jack. Why would you even think that?" She took a step back, her eyes darting around the room as if searching for an escape route.

"Because, Emily, I know you too well," Jack said, his voice low and even. "You're a master of evasion, and your eyes are doing the lying for you right now. What's going on, Em? You're not telling me the truth, and I can see it written all over your face."

"Jack, stop it," Emily said, her voice trembling as she tried to laugh it off. "You're being ridiculous. I'm just a little stressed out with work, that's all. I didn't sleep well last night and I'm still trying to get my head around everything that's going on."
